metadata.sermon_title: The God Who Calls, the Child Who Responds—1 Samuel 3
metadata.sermon_start_end: A LOT of sentimental and fatuous things are written about childhood, especially at Christmas. Those who believe in Jesus as Son of God will understand when we say that, actually, the true meaning of Christmas is more for grown-ups than it is for children. [...] The story of Samuel is the story of Israel, and the story of Israel is your story, and mine, and ours — the story of salvation through The Child Who Was to Come, of whom St. Luke says, he “increased in wisdom and in stature, and in favor with God and man.”

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses 1 Samuel 3 as a narrative framework, but it struggles to identify what is unique to this text. It treats the passage more as a 'favorite story' or a 'prototype' rather than a unique revelation. The preacher falls into the trap of using the text to speak about general themes like 'childhood' or 'parenting' rather than the specific, unrepeatable Word in this pericope.
quotes: The narrative of the boy Samuel in the temple of the Lord always had a certain hold on me
Hannah and her little boy are the Old Testament prototypes of Mary and her son, Jesus.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify what the call of Samuel reveals about God's speech that is found nowhere else. Move away from the 'universal appeal' and focus on the specific 'new, current, proclamatory word' of this text.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The exegesis is largely narrative retelling with psychological overlays. While it mentions the corruption of Eli's sons and the rarity of the Word, it lacks depth in Hebrew context or the specific theological weight of the 'Ark' and 'Shiloh' beyond surface-level descriptions. The mention of 'pre-Freudian days' suggests a modern psychological lens rather than a strictly exegetical one.
quotes: The dark part of the story lies with Eli’s own sons... they are the lurking, sinister counterparts
Wordsworth’s saying “The child is father of the man” is more relentlessly true... than the poet, in pre-Freudian days, consciously knew.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the exposition by exploring the specific theological crisis of the 'rare Word' in the context of Israel's history, rather than using psychological categories like 'surrogate father' or 'self-possession'.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete in its description of modern distractions and family dynamics. However, it often leans toward moralism (the duty to teach children) rather than the 'true truth' of the text's application to the zeitgeist. It correctly identifies the 'worthlessness' of having no regard for the Lord as a contemporary issue.
quotes: It would not be a great leap of the imagination to picture Samuel caught up in a drugs-and-sex situation of today
They are bombarded with so many stimuli from every direction... electronically.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Shift the application from 'how we should raise children' to how the specific Word of judgment and call in 1 Samuel 3 'expounds' the modern hearer's existence before God.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a 'story-then-lesson' structure. While there are moments where the text is brought into the present, the exposition of the biblical narrative and the personal anecdotes/moral applications remain largely distinct blocks.
quotes: To that part of the story we now turn.
When this Bible story is told to children... Today we’re hearing the whole story.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid the 're-telling' of the story followed by 'interpretation'. Aim to draw the hearer into the movement of the text itself so that the exposition is simultaneously the application.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The element of 'misery' is present in the description of Eli's failure and the corruption of the sanctuary. 'Redemption' is linked to the call of God. However, the 'gratitude' (sanctification) is framed more as a parental duty than a Spirit-awakened response to the Word.
quotes: Eli has been a spectacular failure as a parent
to have no regard for the Lord is the foundational offense
May we each re-dedicate ourselves to do our part with the children
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Ensure the 'gratitude' section is less about human effort ('do our part') and more about the life lived in response to the grace of being called by name.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: This is a stronger point. The preacher does not shy away from the 'message of doom' for Eli’s house. The contrast between the 'worthless men' and Samuel presents the two ways clearly, including the reality of being 'lost' in time through a lack of regard for the Lord.
quotes: The message Samuel is to deliver is a message of doom for the house of Eli.
God had decreed death and condemnation for the house of Eli.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Connect the 'doom' of Eli's house more directly to the hearer's own 'ultimate possibilities of life design' rather than leaving it as a historical fact about Eli.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the 'telos' at the very end, but the connection feels somewhat tacked on through a parallel with Luke's Gospel. The sermon is more 'God-centric' in a general sense than strictly Christocentric in the Barthian/Dekkerian sense where Christ is the specific content of the grace.
quotes: The story of Samuel is the story of Israel... the story of salvation through The Child Who Was to Come
Hannah and her little boy are the Old Testament prototypes of Mary and her son, Jesus.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Make Christ the 'telos' throughout the sermon. Instead of just a parallel at the end, show how the 'Word that stands forth' in Samuel is the same Word that became flesh.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1950 words, the sermon meets the 20-minute threshold. It allows for some breadth, though much of that breadth is occupied by personal reminiscence rather than exegetical depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Replace the anecdotal 'family letters' and 'grandmother' stories with deeper theological reflection on the nature of the Word of God to achieve 'depth through breadth'.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s ideal primarily by substituting psychological and anecdotal depth for exegetical and dogmatic depth. While it correctly identifies the seriousness of the 'two ways' regarding Eli’s sons and the necessity of the Word, it leans too heavily on the 'favorite story' motif and moralistic applications regarding parenting. The Christological connection is present but functional rather than central.
strengths: Adequate length to allow for narrative development.
Clear articulation of the 'misery' of Eli's house and the seriousness of judgment.
Effective identification of the 'zeitgeist' regarding digital distractions and the loss of biblical literacy.
weaknesses: Over-reliance on personal anecdotes (grandmother, sister) which distracts from the specific Bible passage.
Psychological categories (Freud, surrogate father) occasionally overshadow the theological exposition.
The application tends toward moralism (parental duties) rather than the 'present of revelation'.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a traceable and adequate address, but it only partially qualifies as a 'sermon' by Dekker's strict criteria. It risks being a 'speech about a biblical character' rather than the actualization of the written Word into a new, current, proclamatory word. The preacher must silence the 'psychology' more effectively to let the text speak its unique truth.
